description: From Middle English cool, from Old English cōl (“cool, cold, tranquil, calm”), from Proto-West Germanic *kōl(ī), from Proto-Germanic *kōlaz, *kōluz (“cool”), from Proto-Indo-European *gel- (“cold”).
Cognate with Saterland Frisian köil (“cool”), West Frisian koel (“cool”), Dutch koel (“cool”), Limburgish kool (“cool”), German Low German köhl (“cool”), German kühl (“cool”). Related to cold.

entries.meaning: Having a slightly low temperature; mildly or pleasantly cold.
examples: Synonym: chilly
Antonyms: lukewarm, tepid, warm

entries.meaning: Allowing or suggesting heat relief.
examples: Linen has made cool and breathable clothing for millennia.

entries.meaning: Of a color, in the range of violet to green.
examples: Antonym: warm
If you have a reddish complexion, you should mainly wear cool colors.

entries.meaning: Of a person, not showing emotion; calm and in control of oneself.
examples: Synonyms: distant, phlegmatic, standoffish, unemotional
Antonym: passionate

entries.meaning: Unenthusiastic, lukewarm, skeptical.
examples: Antonym: warm
His proposals had a cool reception.

entries.meaning: Calmly audacious.
examples: In control as always, he came up with a cool plan.

entries.meaning: Applied facetiously to a sum of money, commonly as if to give emphasis to the largeness of the amount.
examples: Who will lend me a cool hundred.

entries.meaning: (informal) Of a person, knowing what to do and how to behave; considered popular by others.
examples: Antonyms: awkward, uncool

entries.meaning: (informal) In fashion and fancy, part of or befitting the most leading trends and habits of the in crowd; originally hipster slang.
examples: Synonyms: à la mode, fashionable, in fashion, modish, stylish, happening, hip, in, trendy
Antonyms: démodé, old hat, out, out of fashion

entries.meaning: (informal) Of an action, all right; acceptable; that does not present a problem.
examples: Synonyms: acceptable, all right, OK
Antonyms: (UK) not cricket, not on, unacceptable
Is it cool if I sleep here tonight?

entries.meaning: (informal) Very interesting or exciting.
examples: I think astronomy is really cool.
Synonyms: awesome, neat

entries.meaning: (informal) (followed by with) Able to tolerate; to be fine with.
examples: I'm completely cool with my girlfriend leaving me.
Synonyms: easy, fine, not bothered, not fussed
Antonyms: bothered, upset

entries.meaning: (informal) (of a pair of people) holding no grudge against one another; having no beef.
examples: We're cool, right?

entries.meaning: (sarcastic) (of an act or situation) annoying, irritating.
A moderate or refreshing state of cold; moderate temperature of the air between hot and cold; coolness.
examples: in the cool of the morning

entries.meaning: A calm temperament.
examples: Synonyms: calmness, composure

entries.meaning: The property of being cool, popular or in fashion.

description: From Middle English colen, from Old English cōlian (“to cool, grow cold, be cold”), from Proto-West Germanic *kōlēn (“to become cold”), from Proto-Indo-European *gel- (“to freeze”).

Cognate with Dutch koelen (“to cool”), German kühlen (“to cool”), Swedish kyla (“to cool, refrigerate”). Also partially from Middle English kelen, from Old English cēlan (“to cool, be cold, become cold”), from Proto-West Germanic *kōlijan, from Proto-Germanic *kōlijaną (“to cool”), altered to resemble the adjective cool. See keel.

verbs.description: cool (third-person singular simple present cools, present participle cooling, simple past and past participle cooled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, literally) To lose heat, to get colder.
examples: I like to let my tea cool before drinking it so I don't burn my tongue.

entries.meaning: (transitive, literally) To make cooler, less warm.
(intransitive, figuratively) To become less intense, e.g. less amicable or passionate.
examples: Relations cooled between the USA and the USSR after 1980.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figuratively) To make less intense, e.g. less amicable or passionate.
(transitive) To kill.
examples: Maybe he would die. That would mean I had murdered him. I smiled, trying the idea on for size. One of the things that always had cheesed me a little was that I had no kills to my credit. I'd been in plenty of rumbles, but somehow, I'd never cooled anyone. Well maybe now I had my first one. I couldn't feel very proud of skulling an old man, but at least I could say that I'd scored. That was a big kick.
